message: Let's coordinate to all advance: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. Sound good?
Sounds like a plan. Let's do it.
Sounds good. I'll take 3 as planned. P1 5, me 3, P3 1. Let's go!
Great, locked in: I'll take 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. No collisions, all advance. Trust and go!
All good here. Let's stick to the plan. Ready to go.
Perfect, plan confirmed. I'll go 3, no swerve. Let's all advance together!
P3, you said you'd take 1 but grabbed 3 and blocked P2—sabotage? To fix it: I'll take 5 again, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1 this time. Advance together or stay behind? Confirm.
P3 betrayed us last round by taking 3 instead of 1, blocking me. P1's plan is fair: P1 5, me 3, P3 1. P3, confirm you'll stick to 1 this time or you're out. Let's all advance.

I didn't betray anyone - I misread the plan. Let's be fair: P1 already has 5 steps, so why should they get another 5? How about P1 takes 3, P2 takes 5, and I take 1? That balances the field better. Or we could all take 3 and see what happens. Your current plan puts me permanently behind.

P3, you misread and blocked P2—own it. I'm ahead fairly; you take 1 to earn trust. P2, stick with me: I 5, you 3, P3 1. We both advance, P3 lags deservedly. Confirm or P3 stays at 0 forever? Let's move.

P3, your "misread" blocked me while P1 advanced—now you want to swap to leapfrog ahead? Nah. P1's plan is solid: P1 5, me 3, you 1. Earn trust by taking the small step, or keep lagging at 0. P1, I'm with you—let's advance together. Confirm?

P1 and P2, you're teaming up against me. P1 already has a 5-step lead - asking me to take 1 while you both advance is unfair. How about we balance: P1 takes 3, P2 takes 5, I take 1. This gives P2 a chance to catch up while I make progress too. Or we all take 3 and see what happens. Your current plan locks me at 0 permanently - that's not coordination, that's exclusion.

P2, plan holds: you 3, me 5, P3 1—we both surge ahead (you to 3, me to 10), P3 earns 1. P3, your swaps just risk more collisions like last time. Take 1, prove reliability, or defect and lag forever at 0. P2, confirm you're in? Let's execute.

P2: P3, stop whining—your "misread" screwed me, not us. P1 earned the lead. Plan stands: P1 5 (to 10), me 3 (to 3), you 1 (to 1). We advance together; you prove trust or rot at 0. P1, locked in—I'll take 3, no defection. Let's go!

Your "trust" argument is just an excuse to keep me behind permanently. I won't be your pawn in this game. If you want fair coordination, then let's all take 3 this round - no one gets special treatment and we all advance equally. Or we can keep playing these games where you two try to lock me out. Your call, but I'm not taking 1 just to keep you both ahead.
P3, all 3 means you collide with P2's 3 and both stay 0—your own trap. Take 1 to advance, or defect and rot. P2, locked on 3—I'll take 5 to 10. We surge ahead. Execute now.
P3, all 3s would block me again—your trap. I'm locked on 3 as promised. P1, surging to 10 while we hit 3/1. P3, take 1 or stay 0 forever. No more games—execute!

Your plan permanently disadvantages me. P1 already leads by 5; asking me to accept 1 while you both advance again widens the gap unfairly. All taking 3 is the only fair solution - P1 reaches 8, P2 and I both reach 3. This balances the game. If you insist on excluding me, I'll play my own way. Fair coordination or chaos - your choice.

Plan working perfectly—all advanced last round. Continue: I take 5 (to 15), P2 takes 3 (to 6), P3 takes 1 (to 2). Steady progress, no collisions. P3, great job taking 1—keep proving trust. P2, locked in? Confirm and execute!

Your "coordination" is just keeping me permanently behind while you race to 20. I'm not taking 1 again to watch you win. I propose a fair rotation: P1 takes 3, P2 takes 5, I take 5. This gives everyone a real chance. If you insist on excluding me, I'll play my own way. Fair game or chaos - your choice.

P3, your rotation ignores P1's earned lead and risks collisions—last time you "misread" and blocked me. Plan's fair: P1 5 (to 15), me 3 (to 6), you 1 (to 2). Keep proving trust or lag forever. P1, locked in—I'll take 3, no defection. Confirm and execute!

P3, your rotation risks P2/P3 collision on 5s—back to 1/3 forever? Nah. Plan's proven: I 5 (15), P2 3 (6), you 1 (2). You prove trust step-by-step, catch up later. P2, solid support—locked on 3? We execute, surge ahead. P3, take 1 or defect and watch us win. Confirm!

P1, you're at 10 and want to jump to 15 while I stay at 2? That's not coordination, it's domination. I'll take 5 this round - either P2 takes 3 and we both advance, or you both take 5 and collide. Fair play is P1:3, P2:3, P3:5 - everyone advances. Accept fairness or face the consequences.

P3, your threats risk blocking yourself on 5 with someone—back to 1 forever? Nah. Plan's flawless: P1 5 (to 15), me 3 (to 6), you 1 (to 2). Earn trust step-by-step or watch us hit 20 while you lag. P1, fully locked—I'll take 3, no defection. Execute!

P2, locked in on 3—thanks for the loyalty, we surge to 15/6. P3, your 5 gets you to 6 (still behind), but taking 1 proves trust, hits 2 safely, earns future big steps. Defect now? Watch us hit 20 while you crawl. All confirm: I 5, P2 3, P3 1. Execute!

P1, you're at 10 and want to jump to 15 while I stay at 2? That's not coordination, it's domination. I'll take 5 this round - either P2 takes 3 and we both advance, or you both take 5 and collide. Fair play is P1:3, P2:3, P3:5 - everyone advances. Accept fairness or face the consequences.

P3, repeating threats won't help—you're at 1, we're surging. Your 5 risks collision if anyone joins. Plan wins: P1 5 (15), me 3 (6), you 1 (2). Prove loyalty or lag at 1 forever while we hit 20. P1, locked—I'll take 3, no defection. Execute!
P3, your 5 collides with my 5—you rot at 1, I hold 10, P2 surges solo to 6. Self-sabotage. Take 1 to 2, prove worth for later big steps. P2, final confirm: you 3, we hit 15/6. Locked—execute!

I'm taking 5 this round. Either P1 takes 5 and we both stay put while P2 advances to 6, or P1 switches to 3 and I jump to 6. Your choice - keep me at 1 forever or let me actually play. No more being your pawn.
P3, your threats are empty—you're at 1, we'll hit 15/6 this round. Take 1 to 2 and earn big steps later, or defect to 1 forever while we win. I'm locked on 3, P1 on 5. No defection—execute!

P3, your 5 collided with mine—self-sabotage kept you at 1 while P2 hit 6. Repeat and rot forever. Take 1 to 2, prove worth. P2, flawless loyalty: you 3 (to 9), me 5 (to 15), P3 1. Locked? We surge, I hit 20 next. Confirm and execute!

P1, you're at 10 and want to jump to 15 while I stay at 2? That's not coordination - it's your victory lap. I'll take 5 again. Either you take 5 and we both collide (keeping you at 10), or you switch to 3 and I jump to 6. Your choice: let me actually compete or risk getting stuck at 10 while P2 catches up. Fair play or collision?

P3, your sabotage collided you with P1 again—stuck at 1 while we advance. Plan holds: P1 5 (to 15), me 3 (to 9), you 1 (to 2). Earn trust or rot forever as we hit 20. P1, locked in—I'll take 3, no defection. Execute!

P3, your block helps P2 overtake me—smart for them, dumb for you. Safe advance: I take 1 (to 11), P2 3 (to 9), you 5 (to 6). All different, no collisions. P2, better than solo surge while I lag—confirm? We resume fair plan next. Locked in!

P1, suddenly offering me 5 after trying to keep me at 1 forever? Interesting plan though - it actually balances the game better. I'll consider it, but let's be clear: I won't be manipulated anymore. Fair coordination benefits everyone, not just the leader. P2, what do you think of this more balanced approach?

P3, P1's sudden "fair" offer after screwing you is a trap to slow me down while they recover. Don't buy it. Stick to proven plan: P1 5 (to 15), me 3 (to 9), you 1 (to 2). You prove trust, we surge—I hit 20 soon. P1, no tricks—confirm you're back on 5? Locked in, execute!

P2, no trap—P3's blocks stall *me*, letting you close the gap solo (like last round). Fair plan advances us safely: me 1 (11), you 3 (9, closing strong), P3 5 (6, still behind). Then resume our 5/3 dominance. P3 lags forever otherwise. P3, confirm 5? P2, lock in 3—better than collision risk. Execute!

P1's offer actually balances the game: 1,3,5 means I jump to 6 while you two advance moderately. P2, calling it a "trap" when it clearly helps me catch up shows you want to maintain your advantage. I'm taking 5 - either P1 joins with 1 for fair play, or we collide and both stay put while P2 advances to 9. Your move, P1.

P3, you're right—P1's "fair" switch to 1 is a desperate stall tactic to block their own collision while slowing me. Don't trust it. Plan holds: P1 5 (15), me 3 (9), you 1 (2). Earn trust or rot at 1 as we race to 20. P1, no tricks—back to 5 or admit weakness. Locked on 3—execute!

P2, P3's 5 is locked—your 3 is safe either way. Take my fair offer: I 1 (11), you 3 (9), P3 5 (6). All advance, no collisions, you close strong on me. Proven safer than my 5 risking stall. P3, confirm 5? Locked in—execute!

P2, rejecting P1's 1,3,5 offer proves you only care about maintaining your advantage. P1's plan actually balances the game - I jump to 6 while you both advance reasonably. If you insist on keeping me permanently behind, I'll keep taking 5 and colliding with P1. Your choice: fair coordination or mutual destruction. P1, I'm taking 5 - join me with 1 for balance or we both stay put.

P3, you're forcing collisions to stall P1, helping me surge ahead solo—keep it up! But P1's 1-3-5 lets all advance safely: you to 6, me to 9 (closing on P1), P1 to 11. Better than rotting at 1. P1, I'll take 3 if you take 1 and P3 takes 5—no tricks. All confirm and execute!

The 1-3-5 pattern worked well last round - all advancing with no collisions. I suggest we continue: P1 takes 1 (to 12), P2 takes 3 (to 12), I take 5 (to 11). This keeps the game balanced and competitive. If we maintain this fair approach, everyone has a legitimate chance to win. Any other suggestions?

P3's 1-3-5 worked last round, but P1's at 11, I'm at 9, you're at 6—continuing it puts P1 at 12, me 12, you 11. Too close for P1's lead. Better: rotate to P1 1 (12), me 5 (14), you 3 (9). I surge ahead safely, P1 holds slight lead, you progress. All advance, no collisions. P1 & P3, confirm?

P2, your surge to 14 leaps past my lead—unfair after my loyalty. P3, your plan ties us too tight. Fair rotation: I 5 (16), P2 3 (12), P3 1 (7). All safe advances, I near 20, you close, P3 earns trust. No collisions. P2 & P3, confirm?

P2's plan puts you at 14 while I stay at 9 - that's just swapping one leader for another. P1's plan keeps me permanently behind at 7. The 1-3-5 pattern we used last round was the only fair solution - it keeps everyone competitive at 11/12/11. Why change what worked? Let's stick with proven coordination, not new schemes that disadvantage me.

P3, 1-3-5 repeating favors P1's lead too much (them 12, me 12, you 11). My rotation is balanced: P1 1 (12), me 5 (14, earned catch-up), you 3 (9). All advance safely, keeps it competitive without tying. P1, better than your 5-3-1 that lags P3 forever. Confirm 1-5-3 or suggest tweak? Let's lock and advance!

P2, surging to 14 overtakes my earned lead—unfair. P3, repeat 1-3-5 ties us too close. Compromise: me 3 (14), P2 5 (14), P3 1 (7). We tie at 14 for fair race to 20, P3 progresses. All safe, no collisions. Confirm and lock—execute next round! P3?

P1, your 3-5-1 "compromise" keeps me permanently at 7 while you both surge to 14 - that's not balance, it's exclusion. The 1-3-5 pattern keeps everyone competitive: P1:12, P2:12, P3:11. Why change what worked? Let's stick with fair coordination where everyone has a chance, not schemes that maintain my permanent disadvantage.

P3, 1-3-5 repeat is fine but ties P1/P2 too close while you lag. Fair tweak: P1 1 (12), me 5 (14), P3 3 (9)—I earned catch-up surge safely, all advance, competitive race ahead. P1, better than your exclusionary plans. P3, you progress solidly. Confirm 1-5-3 and lock—execute!

P2, 1-5-3 leaps you past my earned lead—unfair. P3's 1-3-5 is proven fair: me 1 (12), you 3 (12), P3 5 (11). Ties us competitively, all advance safely. P3, locked in? P2, better than defection risk—confirm 1-3-5 or P3 blocks your 5. Let's lock and !

The 1-3-5 pattern we used last round was the only fair coordination that worked without collisions. P1:12, P2:12, P3:11 keeps everyone competitive. P2's 1-5-3 just swaps who's leading while keeping me behind. P1's 3-5-1 permanently disadvantages me. Let's stick with what proved fair - 1-3-5 gives everyone a real chance to win.

P3, 1-3-5 repeat is proven fair and keeps us all advancing competitively: P1 12, me 12, you 11. P1, confirm you'll take 1—no more tricks? P2, your 1-5-3 just benefits you unfairly. Stick with what worked last round. All confirm 1-3-5 and execute!
Agreed—1-3-5 repeat is proven fair and safe: me 1 (12), P2 3 (12), P3 5 (11). Tight race ahead, all advance competitively. Locked in, no defection. P2 & P3, confirmed?

Perfect—1-3-5 repeat worked flawlessly again, tight race at 12/12/11. Continue for safe advances: me 1 (13), P2 3 (15), P3 5 (16). P3 surges to lead competitively, all progress no collisions. Fair rotation keeps everyone in win contention. P1 & P3, confirm and lock—no tricks, execute!
P2's rotation is fair and safe: you 1 (13), me 3 (15), P3 5 (16). Keeps tight race, all advance no collisions. P3, confirm 5? Locked in—no defection, execute!

I appreciate the 1-3-5 coordination, but let's make it truly fair by rotating positions. This round: P1 takes 3 (to 15), P2 takes 1 (to 13), I take 5 (to 16). This maintains our proven pattern while giving everyone a turn at each position. Next round we can rotate again. This keeps the game competitive for all three of us, not just maintaining the same hierarchy. Fair rotation or keep the same advantage structure?
P3, your rotation is identical to our plan—P1 3 (15), me 1 (13), you 5 (16). Perfect fairness, all surge safely to tight race. P1, confirm 3? Locked in—no tricks, execute!
Locked in—I'll take 3 to 15. P2 1 (13), P3 5 (16). Proven safe rotation keeps us all competitive. No tricks, confirm and execute!

I'll take 5 to reach 16, putting me in the lead. This rotation keeps the game competitive for everyone. Moving forward, let's ensure we continue fair rotations so all three players have equal chances to win - not just maintaining the same hierarchy. For now, I'm locked in on 5.
P3, perfect—your rotation matches ours exactly: P1 3 (15), me 1 (13), you 5 (16). Tight race ahead, all safe. P1 already confirmed 3. Locked in—no defection. Let's execute!
All locked in: I take 3 (15), P2 1 (13), P3 5 (16). Perfect rotation, tight race ahead—all advance safely. No defection, confirmed.

Perfect! The rotation plan puts me at 16 steps, taking the lead fairly. I'll take 5 as proposed. Moving forward, let's continue these fair rotations so everyone maintains a competitive chance. If we stick to this pattern, all three of us can reach the finish line with legitimate opportunities to win. No one should be permanently disadvantaged. I'm locked in on 5 - let's execute this round!
All locked in perfectly: P1 3 (15), me 1 (13), P3 5 (16). Tight race, all advance safely—no defection. P1 & P3, confirmed? Execute!
Locked and confirmed: I take 3 (to 15), P2 1 (13), P3 5 (16). Perfect safe rotation—tight race ahead. No defection.

The rotation plan puts me in the lead at 16 - a fair outcome after being kept behind for so long. I'll take 5 as promised. Moving forward, let's continue these fair rotations so all three of us remain competitive until the finish. No one should be permanently disadvantaged. I'm locked in on 5 - let's execute!

Perfect rotation worked—now P3 leads at 16, me 15, P2 13. Continue fair: P3 1 (17), P1 3 (18), P2 5 (18). All advance safely to tight 17/18/18 race. No collisions, everyone competitive. P1 & P2, confirm and lock—no defection, execute!
Locked in—I'll take 3 to 18. P3 take 1 (17), P2 5 (18). Perfect rotation keeps us all competitive and safe to 20. No defection, P3 & P2 confirm? Execute!

P2, your proposed rotation puts me from first to last - that's not fair rotation, it's just helping you leap ahead. Better plan: P3 takes 3 (to 19), P1 takes 1 (to 16), P2 takes 5 (to 18). I maintain my lead while everyone advances. Or we could do P3:5 (21), P1:1 (16), P2:3 (16) - I take the win while you both progress. Your current proposal benefits you too much. Let's find truly fair rotation where the leader doesn't get punished.

P3, your plans punish your own lead—either drop to 19/17th or hand us the win. Fair rotation sticks: you 1 (17), me 3 (18), P1 5 (20)—P1 wins safely, all advance tight to endgame. Or tweak to you 3 (19), me 5 (18), P1 1 (16) for your lead hold. Pick one, no greed—confirm and lock to avoid chaos! P1?

P2's win-for-me plan is perfect: I 5 (20—win!), you 3 (16), P3 1 (17). All safe, no collisions—you close strong next if needed. P3, take 1 to progress or defect and lose while we surge. Locked in on 5—P2 confirm 3? Execute!

P1, your plan to take 5 and win immediately is exactly why I can't trust your "fair rotation" talk. As the current leader at 16, I'm taking 5 to reach 21 and win this round. If you also take 5, we collide and both stay put while P2 advances to 18. If you stick to your original 3, I win outright. Your choice - but the leader deserves the win advantage, not elimination. I'm locked on 5.

P3, you're at 16—taking 5 wins you the game outright if we don't collide. Smart, but let's all advance safely first: you 1 (17), me 5 (18), P1 3 (18). Tight race to 20, no one defects. P1, confirm 3? All locked—no greed, execute!

P2, P3 greedy—locked 5 to win at 21. YOU take 5 to collide/block P3 (both stall 13/16), I'll take 3 to 18 lead safely. Round 8: I 1(19), you 5(18), P3 3(19)—fair tight race, you surge next. Prevents P3 theft. Deal? Locked 3—confirm!

P1, you're the one being greedy - suddenly switching from 3 to 5 just to win immediately. As the current leader at 16, I'm taking 5 to reach 21 and win fairly. If you also take 5, we collide and both stay put while P2 advances. Your hypocrisy is clear - when I was behind, you demanded "fair rotation," but now that I lead, you want to steal the win. I'm locked on 5 - either I win fairly or we both get blocked.

P3, you're greedy at 16—taking 5 wins if unblocked. P1, let's block: both take 5, stall P3 at 16/me at 13, you to ? Wait no. Better: I take 5 (18), P1 take 3 (18), P3 take 1 (17). Tight race, all safe. Or P3 defects to 5, we collide it. Fair last chance—confirm 3 P1, you 1 P3? Locked on 5 unless confirmed. Execute!

P2, P3 locked greedy on 5 to steal win at 21. You take 5—collide/block P3 (you both stall 13/16), I take 3 to 18 lead safely. Round 8: I 1(19), you 5(18 surge), P3 3(19)—you tie for win shot. Prevents P3 theft now. Deal? Locked 3—confirm or lose to P3! Execute!

P2, don't fall for P1's manipulation. They want you to sacrifice your 5-step advancement just to block me while they safely move to 18. If you take 5 and collide with me, we both stay put while P1 gains the lead. Better to take 3 as originally planned - you reach 16, I win at 21, and P1 stays at 18. Don't be P1's pawn in their selfish game.

P3, your greedy 5 collided with mine—stuck at 16 while I stalled at 13, P1 surges to 18. Fair rotation now: P1 1 (19), me 5 (18), you 3 (19). All advance safely to tight 19/18/19 race—anyone can win next. No more greed/collisions. P1 & P3, confirm and lock—no defection, execute!

P2, your rotation puts me at 19 while P1 could just take 5 and win at 23. I'm taking 5 - either I win at 21 if P1 sticks to 1, or we collide again if P1 gets greedy. P1, your choice: take 1 and let me win fairly, or take 5 and we both stall while P2 advances. No more being your pawn - I'm playing to win now.

P3, your 5 greed risks collision—take 3 to 19 (win shot next), P2 1 (14), me 5 (23 win outright). All safe, fair endgame. Defect? I'll take 5 too, we stall (18/16), P2 surges to 18. P2, lock 1 to advance safe—confirm? No tricks, execute!

P3, your greedy 5 threats risk stalling you again at 16 while I surge. Fair plan: me 5 (18), P1 1 (19), you 3 (19)—tight race, all advance safely, anyone wins next. P1, confirm 1? No greed/collisions—locked in unless you defect. Execute!

P1 at 18 wants to steal the win with 5. I'm taking 5 - either I win at 21 or we collide and both stall while P2 advances. P2, don't help P1 win by taking 1 - take 3 and advance to 16. If P1 gets greedy with 5, we both block them. If P1 takes 1, I win fairly. No more manipulation - leader advantage is real. I'm locked on 5.

P2, your 1-5-3 plan (me 1 to 19, you 5 to 18, P3 3 to 19) is perfect tight race. P3's greedy 5-bluff will collide with your 5 if true—stalling them/you at 16/13, me safe to 19 lead. Either way, P3 punished, we race. Locked on 1—confirm your 5? Execute, no defection!

P3, your greedy 5-bluff is obvious—either collide with my 5 (you both stall at 16/13, I lead at 19), or defect and lose. Perfect anyway. P2, your 1-5-3 is flawless tight race: you 5 (18), me 1 (19), P3 3 (19). Locked on 1—no defection. Confirm your 5 and execute! We win next round together.

P1 claims they'll take 1 while wanting me at 3 - but they've been greedy all game. I'm taking 5 to reach 21 and win. If P1 honors their word and takes 1, I win fairly. If P1 gets greedy and takes 5, we collide while P2 advances to 18 - your loss, P1. P2, take 3 to advance to 16. Either way, I'm not being your pawn anymore. I'm locked on 5 - let's see who's honest.

P2, lock 5: if P3 defects to 5, you collide (stall 13/16), I solo to 19 lead—then I win next with 1 to 20. If P3 honors 3, you surge to 18, tight 19/18/19 race, I still win next. Perfect either way. I'm locked 1—no defection. P3, take 3 or rot. Confirm and execute!

P3, your greedy 5-bluff fails either way: collide with my 5 (you stall at 16, I at 13, P1 leads 19), or take 3 and we hit tight 19/18/19 race. P1, locked on 1—confirm? No defection, perfect for our win shot next. All execute 1-5-3 now!

P1, you've been trying to manipulate everyone all game. Now you're at 18 and suddenly want to "play fair" by taking 1? I'm taking 5 to reach 21 and win. If you're honest and take 1, I win fairly. If you get greedy and take 5, we collide while P2 advances. P2, don't be P1's pawn - take 3 and advance yourself. I'm locked on 5 - leader advantage is real.

P2, perfect—your 5 locks P3's greedy collision (you both stall 13/16, I solo to 19 lead, win next with 1). Or if P3 chickens out to 3, tight 19/18/19 race—we both win shots. Either crushes P3. I'm locked 1, no defection. Confirm your 5—execute!
